user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_irq_register_controller:
```c
int metal_irq_register_controller(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr)
{
	int irq_base;
	struct metal_list *node;

	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		if (node == &cntr->node) {
			return 0;
		}
	}

	/*
	 * Allocate IRQ numbers which are not yet used by any IRQ
	 * controllers.
	 */
	irq_base = metal_irq_allocate(cntr->irq_base, cntr->irq_num);
	if (irq_base == METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	cntr->irq_base = irq_base;

	metal_list_add_tail(&irq_cntrs, &cntr->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_irq_register_controller:
static int metal_irq_allocate(int irq_base, int irq_num)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;
	int irq_tocheck = irq_base, irq_end_tocheck;

	if (irq_num == 0) {
		return METAL_IRQ_ANY;
	}
	if (irq_tocheck == METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
		irq_tocheck = 0;
	}
	irq_end_tocheck = irq_tocheck + irq_num;

	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		int cntr_irq_base, cntr_irq_end;

		cntr = metal_container_of(node,
					  struct metal_irq_controller, node);
		cntr_irq_base = cntr->irq_base;
		cntr_irq_end = cntr_irq_base + cntr->irq_num;
		if (irq_tocheck < cntr_irq_end &&
		    irq_end_tocheck > cntr_irq_base) {
			if (irq_base != METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
				/* IRQ has been allocated */
				return METAL_IRQ_ANY;
			}
			irq_tocheck = cntr_irq_end;
			irq_end_tocheck = irq_tocheck + irq_num;
		}
	}
	return irq_tocheck;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No direct self-call (neither function contains a call to itself). The only potential recursion points to inspect are the function/macro call sites listed above because they invoke other code that could (in theory) call back into these functions. The remaining code fragments are simple control flow, arithmetic and return statements with no function calls and thus cannot introduce direct or indirect recursion (e.g. the NULL check, comparisons, arithmetic on irq_base/irq_num, and the return statements). Additionally, in the provided definitions metal_irq_allocate does not call metal_irq_register_controller, and the listed list-manipulation macros (metal_list_for_each, metal_list_add_tail, metal_container_of) are standard non-recursive list helpers; they should be inspected to confirm they do not call back into the functions, but other lines need no further investigation for Rule 17.2.
